body_html:
I think the point is that auto-generated list/dict wrappers which don't have any variables or checkpointable objects associated with them shouldn't count as a checkpoint not matching. Otherwise self._unused_list = [] would break an assertion, which is technically correct-ish but not helpful. I could have conditionals in my init which only sometimes assign such an attribute, in which case small configuration changes would accidentally break assertions.

Either way the checkpoint restore works fine, since no variables were added or tracked in a different way. It's just a question of whether the optional assertions pass or not.

Either way the checkpoint restore works fine, since no variables were added or tracked in a different way. It's just a question of whether the optional assertions pass or not.
body:
I think the point is that auto-generated list/dict wrappers which don't have any variables or checkpointable objects associated with them shouldn't count as a checkpoint not matching. Otherwise `self._unused_list = []` would break an assertion, which is technically correct-ish but not helpful. I could have conditionals in my __init__ which only sometimes assign such an attribute, in which case small configuration changes would accidentally break assertions.

Either way the checkpoint restore works fine, since no variables were added or tracked in a different way. It's just a question of whether the optional assertions pass or not.
